results.title: ‘The Worst Person in the World’ Review: Oslo, Her Way
results.abstract: Renate Reinsve stars in Joachim Trier’s funny-sad story of a woman on the verge of figuring herself out.
des_facet: The Worst Person in the World (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Renate Reinsve and Anders Danielsen Lie in “The Worst Person in the World,” from the director Joachim Trier.

results.title: ‘Jackass Forever’ Review: A Visit From the Goon Squad
results.abstract: Sharp cinematography and enviable camaraderie continue to hoist Johnny Knoxville and friends above their many imitators in this deceptively kindhearted sequel.

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from left: Johnny Knoxville, Rachel Wolfson, Steve-O and Sean McInerney in “Jackass Forever.”

results.title: Can Jennifer Lopez Save the Rom-Com?
results.abstract: After navigating the treacherous waters of celebrity, the superstar is betting on “Marry Me,” a movie that sounds a lot like her personal life.

multimedia.caption: The new film is in some ways about what it’s like to exist in Jennifer Lopez’s spotlight, what she calls “a very specific life.”
multimedia.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

results.title: Who Will Be Nominated for the Oscars? Here Are Our Projections.
results.abstract: The list will be unveiled Feb. 8. Our expert’s predictions are based on precursor awards and industry scuttlebutt. But in an unusually open year, he’d love to be wrong.

multimedia.caption: Unlike previous years, no other awards will have been handed out before the Oscar nominations are unveiled next week.

results.title: Watch the Throne: How Joel Coen Came to Make ‘The Tragedy of Macbeth’
results.abstract: When your whole filmmaking career has been one of unexpected twists and turns, how do you surprise yourself? Adapt a Shakespeare play.

multimedia.caption: Joel Coen during production of “The Tragedy of Macbeth.” He came to the play “as an amateur,” he said. “I’m still an amateur.”

results.title: Monica Vitti, ‘Queen of Italian Cinema,’ Dies at 90
results.abstract: Both sensual and cerebral, she made her mark on the international scene in the 1960s, when visionary directors like Michelangelo Antonioni were remaking the cinema landscape.

multimedia.caption: Monica Vitti, center, in a scene from Michelangelo Antonioni’s 1960 movie, “L’Avventura.” Antonioni was her companion for a decade, and she was his muse and alter ego.

results.title: ‘The Lost City’ and a Richard Linklater Film Will Play SXSW
results.abstract: The film festival will return to primarily in-person screenings in Austin, Texas, with some online options.
des_facet: South by Southwest Music and Media Conference
The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent (Movie)

multimedia.caption: From left, Brad Pitt, Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum in “The Lost City.”

results.title: ‘Breaking Bread’ Review: Peace Meals
results.abstract: This documentary follows the preparations for a food festival at which chefs from Arab and Jewish backgrounds team up to create dishes together.

multimedia.caption: Shlomi Meir, left, with Ali Khattib in the documentary “Breaking Bread.”

results.title: These Talkies Star Complicated Women You Might Well Recognize
results.abstract: A MoMA series puts the spotlight on a Hollywood era when actresses broke free of stereotypes that would later dominate movies for decades.
des_facet: The Bitter Tea of General Yen (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Clara Bow in “The Wild Party” (1929), directed by Dorothy Arzner, part of the series “Dames, Janes, Dolls and Canaries.”
multimedia.copyright: via The Museum of Modern Art Film Stills Archive

results.title: ‘Lingui, the Sacred Bonds’ Review: Love, Ferocious and Limitless
results.abstract: In this electric liberation story from Chad, a mother struggles to protect her daughter’s future and finds both herself and a world of possibility.

multimedia.caption: Rihane Khalil Alio, left, and Achouackh Abakar Souleymane in Mahamat-Saleh Haroun’s “Lingui, the Sacred Bonds.”

results.title: ‘Alone With You’ Review: An Anniversary for One
results.abstract: A woman hoping for a romantic night with her girlfriend instead finds herself trapped in her Brooklyn apartment, facing down demons.

multimedia.caption: Emily Bennett as Charlie in “Alone With You.”

results.title: ‘Moonfall’ Review: Out of Orbit
results.abstract: Halle Berry and Patrick Wilson save the world from a rogue moon in the latest disaster movie from the director of “Independence Day.”

multimedia.caption: Halle Berry and Patrick Wilson in “Moonfall.”

results.title: Jean-Jacques Beineix, ‘Cinema du Look’ Director, Dies at 75
results.abstract: His first feature, “Diva,” a visually unusual tale, is credited with starting a new, style-focused genre of filmmaking in France.

multimedia.caption: Jean-Jacques Beineix, whose films were distinguished by their visual-forward style, was credited with creating a genre known as the cinéma du look.

results.title: ‘Dune’ and ‘The Power of the Dog’ Lead BAFTA Nominees
results.abstract: Dennis Villeneuve’s sci-fi epic and Jane Campion’s western secured the most nominations in a lineup notable for its diversity.
des_facet: The Worst Person in the World (Movie)
org_facet: British Academy of Film and Television

multimedia.caption: Benedict Cumberbatch in “The Power of the Dog,” which was nominated for eight BAFTA awards on Thursday.

results.title: ‘Poly Styrene: I Am a Cliché’ Review: An Overdue Close-up
results.abstract: In this new documentary, Poly Styrene’s daughter grapples tenderly with the legacy of her punk rock mother.
des_facet: Poly Styrene: I Am a Cliche (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Poly Styrene as seen in the new documentary “Poly Styrene: I Am a Cliché.”

results.title: Watch These 11 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
results.abstract: February’s exodus includes two best picture winners and a lot more. Catch these while you can.

multimedia.caption: Arnold Schwarzenegger in a scene from “Terminator 2: Judgment Day.”

results.title: ‘Last Looks’ Review: A Hollywood Murder Mystery Full of Clichés
results.abstract: A former police officer is drawn back into duty in a case involving a drunken TV star, played by Mel Gibson, and the plot thickens.

multimedia.caption: Charlie Hunnam, left, and Mel Gibson in “Last Looks,” directed by Tim Kirkby.

results.title: Sundance Wrap-Up: 6 Movies We Like and One We Disagree on
results.abstract: Even virtual, the festival gave our chief film critics a lot to talk about.
results.byline: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott

multimedia.caption: Salik Rehman in the documentary “All That Breathes,” about Muslim brothers in New Delhi.

results.title: How Poly Styrene Broke the Mold
results.abstract: A biracial woman in a predominantly white, male scene, the X-Ray Spex frontwoman brought fresh perspectives and sounds to punk. A new documentary explores her impact.
des_facet: Poly Styrene: I Am a Cliche (Movie)

multimedia.caption: “Poly Styrene: I Am a Cliché” tells the story of the X-Ray Spex frontwoman, who put her own unique spin on punk rock starting in the late 1970s.
multimedia.copyright: Photo by Gus Stewart/Redferns, via Getty Images

results.title: ‘My Best Friend Anne Frank’ Review: Separated by the Nazis
results.abstract: This film wants to spotlight a story of friendship and childhood innocence during the Holocaust, but feels quaint and misguided.

multimedia.caption: Josephine Arendsen in “My Best Friend Anne Frank.”

results.title: ‘Home Team’ Review: Fumblecore
results.abstract: Kevin James plays the complicated N.F.L. coach Sean Payton in an uncomplicated Netflix family flick.

multimedia.caption: From left, Kevin James, Jackie Sandler and Tait Blum in “Home Team.”

results.title: ‘The Exiles’ and ‘Nanny’ Win Top Prizes at Sundance
results.abstract: A documentary revisiting dissidents from the Tiananmen Square massacre and a horror film about an undocumented domestic worker took the U.S. Grand Jury prizes at the festival.

multimedia.caption: Christine Choy in the directors Ben Klein and Violet Columbus’s “The Exiles,” which won the U.S. Grand Jury Prize for documentary at the Sundance Film Festival.

results.title: Carol Speed, Vixen of the Blaxploitation Era, Dies at 76
results.abstract: In the mid-70s, thanks to two beloved B movies, she had a moment in the spotlight and enjoyed celebrity status in the Black press.

multimedia.caption: The actress Carol Speed in the early 1970s. Her fresh-faced prettiness provided a dramatic contrast to her roles as a demon in “Abby” (1974) and a prostitute in “The Mack” (1973).

results.title: Kamau Bell: Bill Cosby Is Key to Understanding America
results.abstract: The comic and commentator discusses his new documentary, “We Need to Talk About Cosby,” and what Cosby’s story reveals about the “two runaway forces of oppression in America.”
des_facet: We Need to Talk About Cosby (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: The comic and commentator W. Kamau Bell is known as someone who is willing to have difficult conversations, he said. But the one about Bill Cosby was tougher than most.

results.title: A Sundance With Brains and Guts, Disemboweled and Otherwise
results.abstract: This year’s festival featured lots of scares, a parade of bodies (and body parts) and a haunted, haunting postcolonial tale set in New York.

multimedia.caption: Anna Diop in “Nanny,” one of the standouts in this year’s lineup.

results.title: Family of Slain ‘Rust’ Cinematographer Weighs Wrongful-Death Lawsuit
results.abstract: Lawyers for the family of Halyna Hutchins filed a petition in New Mexico to appoint a representative who will consider whether to file a suit.

multimedia.caption: Halyna Hutchins, a cinematographer, was shot and killed on the set of “Rust” by a gun that the actor Alec Baldwin was practicing with on the set.

results.title: ‘The Ice Age Adventures of Buck Wild’ Review: A Franchise Thaws
results.abstract: The latest installment in this animated film series replaces nearly all of its celebrity voice performers with close proxies.
des_facet: The Ice Age Adventures of Buck Wild (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Buck, voiced by Simon Pegg, in “Ice Age: The Adventures of Buck Wild.”

results.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a grim western teeming with bloodthirsty outlaws, humans fighting an alien invasion and more.

multimedia.caption: Stephen Moyer in “Confession.”

results.title: Moses Storm and the Case for Pretentious Modern Stand-up
results.abstract: In his new special, the comic claims he has no agenda, but his jokes and stories about poverty cohere into trenchant commentary. Why are themes out of fashion?

multimedia.caption: Moses Storm in his new special, “Trash White.”

results.title: Woody Allen’s ‘Rifkin’s Festival’ Is Opening in U.S. Theaters
results.abstract: The movie is showing after years of resistance to Allen’s work in the United States following renewed attention to Dylan Farrow’s allegations of sexual abuse.

multimedia.caption: “Rifkin’s Festival,” directed by Woody Allen and starring Gina Gershon and Wallace Shawn, will be viewable in the United States on Friday.

results.title: Directors Guild Nominations Focus on Veterans Like Jane Campion and Steven Spielberg
results.abstract: The films of all five contenders are also up for Producers Guild Awards, suggesting that they will make up the top tier of best-picture nominees at the Oscars.

multimedia.caption: Jane Campion, with the associate producer Phil Jones, on the set of “The Power of the Dog.”

results.title: ‘A Taste of Hunger’ Review: A Relentless Pursuit of Perfection
results.abstract: A husband and wife pour everything into their restaurant in a quest for a Michelin star, heedless of the other dimensions of their lives.

multimedia.caption: From left, Katrine Greis-Rosenthal and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau in “A Taste of Hunger,” directed by Christoffer Boe.

results.title: Writers Guild Nominations: ‘Don’t Look Up,’ ‘Licorice Pizza’ and More
results.abstract: The group’s contenders can be predictive of the Oscars but several films, including “Belfast” and “The Power of the Dog,” weren’t eligible.

multimedia.caption: Leonardo DiCaprio and Jennifer Lawrence in “Don’t Look Up,” with a screenplay by Adam McKay.

results.title: ‘The Fallout’ Review: The Unexpected Effects of Trauma
results.abstract: Jenna Ortega stars as a teenager coping with the aftermath of a school shooting in this grounded and compassionate look at adolescent grief.

multimedia.caption: Jenna Ortega, right, with Julie Bowen in “The Fallout.”
